validationRules.placeholder: Optional string - Suggested URL format (include https:// for clarity)
validationRules.reqTgl: Boolean - true for required fields, false for optional
validationRules.urlImage: Object - {url, Id} for custom image (requires urlIconType: 'image')
validationRules.uniqueid: String - Unique form field identifier for submission data

warnings: Browser URL validation only checks format (protocol://domain), not if URL actually exists
Users can enter fake/invalid URLs even with validation (http://fake.example.com passes)
URL fields do NOT verify SSL certificates or check if site is live
autoComplete='url' exposes user's browsing history (privacy consideration)
urlIconType must be set before urlIcons or urlImage will work
Custom image icons (urlImage) require uploading to WordPress Media Library first
Icon colors (icnClr, hvrIcnClr) only work with fontAwesome icons, not image icons
Don't use URL fields for email addresses (use nxt-email-field instead)
Don't require protocol (https://) in placeholder if users typically omit it
Mobile Safari may auto-capitalize first letter of URL (add autocapitalize='none' via custom CSS)
commonMistakes: Setting urlIcons without urlIconType='fontAwesome' (icon won't display)
Using wrong Font Awesome prefix (fas=solid, fab=brands, far=regular)
Forgetting to include protocol in placeholder (use 'https://example.com' not 'example.com')
Not setting autoComplete='url' for better UX (browser autocomplete helps users)
Using percentage widths that don't add up to 100% in multi-column layouts
Setting reqTgl=true for optional social media fields (frustrates users who don't have accounts)
Using generic error message 'This field is required' instead of 'Please enter a valid URL'
Not providing URL format examples in help text (users enter wrong formats)
Using custom image icons that are too large (>64px causes layout issues)
Not testing responsive breakpoints (md/sm/xs) on actual devices
bestPractices: Always set autoComplete='url' unless privacy is a concern (helps users fill forms faster)
Include protocol (https://) in placeholder text to guide users
Use platform-specific brand colors for social media URL fields (LinkedIn #0077B5, GitHub #24292e)
Provide URL format examples in help text (hlpTxt + desctxt) to reduce errors
Use descriptive error messages: 'Please enter a valid website URL' instead of 'Required field'
For optional fields, use reqTgl=false to avoid forcing users to have every social profile
Use 50% width (inpSz.md: 50) for paired URL fields (Website + Portfolio side by side)
Always set inpSz.xs to 100 for mobile devices (stacks fields vertically)
Choose appropriate icons: fas fa-globe (website), fas fa-link (portfolio), fab fa-{platform} (social)
Use image icons only for custom branding (FontAwesome is faster and scales better)
Test URL validation with edge cases (http vs https, www vs non-www, trailing slashes)
Consider using uniqueid that matches the URL purpose ('linkedin_url', 'github_url') for backend processing
For developer forms, use dark icon colors (#24292e GitHub, #000000 for tech)
For business forms, use professional blues/purples (#667eea, #4F46E5)
Combine with nxt-hidden-field to track URL referrer source for analytics
accessibilityNotes: Label (labelss) is required for screen readers to identify URL input purpose
Placeholder is NOT a replacement for label (placeholders disappear on input)
Use descriptive labels: 'Company Website' not just 'URL'
Help text (desctxt) provides additional context for assistive technology
Error messages (error attribute) are announced by screen readers when validation fails
Icons should be decorative only (screen readers focus on label + help text)
Ensure sufficient color contrast for icon colors (icnClr) - minimum 4.5:1 ratio
Don't rely on icon color alone to convey meaning (use label text)
autoComplete='url' helps users with motor disabilities by reducing typing
Large touch targets on mobile (minimum 44x44px) - default TPGB styling handles this
performanceConsiderations: FontAwesome icons are lighter than custom images (vector vs raster)
If using multiple custom image icons, combine into CSS sprite for fewer HTTP requests
Browser URL validation is instant (no server round trip)
autoComplete='url' loads URLs from browser history (no backend query needed)
Large custom icon images slow down form rendering - optimize to <10KB
Use SVG for custom icons instead of PNG for better scaling and smaller file size
